stem: Complete the triage logic for a client with sudden onset of left-sided weakness.
template: To determine eligibility for tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), the nurse must first obtain {{test}}. The medication is generally administered within {{timeframe}} of the last known normal (LKN) time.

rationale.correct: (1) Non-contrast CT is the fastest way to rule out a hemorrhage. You cannot give 'clot-busters' until you know they aren't bleeding. (2) The standard window for IV tPA (Alteplase) is 3 hours, extended to 4.5 hours in certain low-risk clients.
rationale.incorrect: Troponin is for MI, not stroke. Giving tPA for a hemorrhagic stroke (identified on CT) would be fatal.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "a non-contrast Head CT scan" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "3 to 4.5 hours" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

clinicalPearls: Absolute contraindications for tPA include active internal bleeding, recent intracranial surgery, or BP >185/110.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the patient woke up with symptoms, 'last known normal' is when they went to sleep, not when they woke up. This often disqualifies 'wake-up' strokes from tPA.

mnemonic.title: F-A-S-T
mnemonic.expansion: Face, Arms, Speech, Time (to call 911/get CT).

reviewUnits.heading: Acute Ischemic Stroke Management
reviewUnits.body: Nurses perform q15-min neuro checks during infusion. Blood pressure must be strictly maintained <180/105 after tPA to prevent intracranial hemorrhage.
